awd_titl_txt: RoL:  FELS:  EAGER:  Genetic Constraints on the Increase of Organismal Complexity Over Time
awd_abstract_narration:
In both plants and animals, the emergence of new specialized body parts is rare. Specialized organs appear to originate as specialized versions of existing organs, yet their specialization requires a divergence in regulation between different copies of the same organ.  This project will test a proposed rule of life, that states that the largest and most complex changes in the evolution of multicellular organisms are easier to achieve when the entire set of chromosomes of an organism is duplicated in the course of evolution.  Links between whole genome duplication and an increase in the number of body parts has been suggested to explain the evolution of early tetrapods or the emergence of flowering plants, but these are harder to study experimentally as they have occurred tens or hundreds of millions of years ago. A more recent event is the emergence in corn with two types of inflorescences (group or cluster of flowers arranged on a stem) for male and female reproduction - tassel and ear; contrasting to the situation in close relatives of maize that produce only a single type of inflorescence. This research will use comparative genetics techniques in maize and one such relative, sorghum, to identify which genetic systems, when turned on or off, change the inflorescence types. The project will provide valuable training to undergraduate students, supported by institutional UCARE and REU programs.

This EAGER project tests the hypothesis that the development and evolution of specialized reproductive organs of maize are controlled by the specialized ensembles of duplicate copies of one set of ancestral genes that was required for development of non-specialized sexual organ, before it underwent a duplication in the course of the whole-genome polyploidization. Generation and phenotypic characterization of knockouts of syntenic orthologous genes in polyploidized maize and nonpolyploidized sorghum will provides a systematic test of the Ortholog Conjecture, a rule of life that tells that genes evolved by speciation tend to preserve function, whereas genes produced by duplication tend to evolve related but not identical functions.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Molecular and Cellular Biosciences

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: BOARD OF REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF NEBRASKA

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
This award supported efforts to understand the evolution of the specialized separate reproductive structures of corn/maize (Zea mays): the tassel and ear. Corn, and its wild progenitor teosinte, are unique among their close relatives in the presence of these specialized organs for male and female flower development.

In this study we analyzed gene expression in developing maize tassels and ears and compared the data to expression in developing sorghum inflorescences. Sorghum is a close relative of corn which produces only a single kind of inflorescence instead of two specialized ones. We sought to identify cases where a single gene expressed in sorghum inflorescence development had duplicated in the maize genome and one copy was expressed in the developing tassel and one was expressed in the developing ear. This duplication -- and the mechanism responsible for it, a process called whole genome duplication -- is something that we speculated may be responsible for enabling a trend towards increasing organismal complexity over time. 

After identify a small set of interesting "triplets" (e.g. maize1 gene, sorghum gene, and maize2 gene) we worked with a transformation core faculity to generate new varieties of corn and sorghum with edits that break each of these genes individually to allow us to better understand the function of individual genes. In order to maximize the number of genes we would be able to break, and hence study, with a limited budget, we transformed a single construct that could break three different genes at once, and are now using backcrossing and PCR genotyping to create individual corn and sorghum varieties which only have edits for one gene at a time. While this process is ongoing and will continue after the end of the grant, we are already seeing promising evidence that one of the genes identifies plays a role in meristem development (the pool of stem cells that give rise to plant organs) and a second may play a specific role in anther or pollen repoductive development, and plants carrying a broken version of that gene are male sterile. 

In addition to the core efforts of this project, this grant also enabled a range of addional tool development, including a new method to predict the function of previously unannotated "orphan" genes that does not depend on having experimental evidence of the function of any gene with a similar sequence and a new statistically approach to identifying the subset of genes which are likely to have any visible effect on plants where a copy of the gene is broken. The latter is particularly important as right now editing genes to figure out what their functions are is a time and resource intensive process and in may cases it ends fruitlessly. Identifying which genes are unlikely to produce phenotypes when edited makes research to understand the functions of genes more efficient and more financially viable. 


Last Modified: 03/07/2023
Modified by: James Schnable

Images (1 of )
  • The tassel develops at the top of the corn plant. It is a specialized organ that produces only male flowers. These flowers in turn produce vast amounts of pollen that are distributed by the wind and land on the silks of maize ears fertilizing individual corn kernels.
    Brandi Sigmon
    Royalty-free (unrestricted use)
    James Schnable
    Maize/Corn Tassel
  • The maize ear, like the tassel, is a specialized inflorescence. Unlike the tassel which produces male flowers, the ear produces female flowers, one for each kernel of corn. Each kernel produces a single silk which grows out of the ear shoot and must be individually fertilized by a grain of pollen.
    James Schnable
    Creative Commons
    James Schnable
    Maize/Corn Ear
